title: Oxford University Australian Rules Football Club
text:
Oxford University Australian Rules Football Club (often referred to as OUARFC) is an <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a> club representing the <a href="University%20of%20Oxford">University of Oxford</a> in the United Kingdom. The club operates under the auspices of the Oxford University Sport Federation.
History.
The club was founded in 1906 by Prescott Harper, a <a href="Rhodes%20Scholarship">Rhodes Scholar</a> (Oriel & Western Australia, 1905). The team was initially made up primarily of Rhodes Scholars from Australia and South Africa. The first match against a <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a> team took place on March 18, 1911, in Oxford. The Oxford team was captained by Alfred Clemes, also a Rhodes scholar (Magdalen & Tasmania, 1908). The game was won by Oxford. There is no known record of other games against Cambridge until 1921, when the regular Varsity fixture commenced with the <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Australian%20Rules%20Football%20Club">Cambridge University Australian Rules Football Club</a>. The Varsity Match has continued without any missed fixtures through until 2020. This history makes the AFL Oxford v Cambridge Varsity Match one of the oldest varsity matches, and an early example of the spread of <a href="Australian%20rules%20football%20around%20the%20world">Australian rules football around the world</a>. Women played their first game in OUARFC colours in February 2015, and in 2018 Romy Minko was elected as the club's first female president.
Since its inception in 2018 the club has participated in the National University League of <a href="AFL%20England">AFL England</a>. Teams within this league include the University of Cambridge, <a href="University%20of%20Birmingham">University of Birmingham</a> and a combined team of players from Universities of South Wales. The club also plays occasional games against teams from around the Europe and the UK including the Amsterdam Devils and the Odense Lions.
Team composition and notable players.
Players have included notable <a href="Australian%20people">Australians</a> such as Judges of the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Victoria">Supreme Court of Victoria</a> <a href="Chris%20Maxwell%20%28jurist%29">Chris Maxwell</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Santamaria">Joseph Santamaria</a>, the prominent businessman Sir <a href="Rod%20Eddington">Rod Eddington</a>, mining executive <a href="Andrew%20Michelmore">Andrew Michelmore</a>, and former <a href="AFL%20Commission">AFL Commission</a> Chairman and former <a href="Carlton%20Football%20Club">Carlton Football Club</a> captain <a href="Mike%20Fitzpatrick%20%28footballer%29">Mike Fitzpatrick</a>.
The team often included multiple <a href="Rhodes%20Scholars">Rhodes Scholars</a>, and <a href="John%20Monash%20Scholars">Sir John Monash Scholars</a>, while both teams also often attract an influx of <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> players of Australian heritage. Players from Ireland and Canada have become common as the sport's reach extends internationally, and due to the similarity of the game with <a href="Gaelic%20football">Gaelic Football</a>.
